ci/environments/standalone-ipa.yaml.message: is this ok to remove dnsservers config options but keep dns search domains?
I also second this. Are we going to hit the same issues with this param? If so, we should be deprecating and removing both of them?

DnsSearchDomains will kind of hit the same issue, only if `dns_search_domains` is defined in baremetal deployment YAML definitions[1] `network_config` section.

When the inventory is generated, we do it in stages:

  #1 From information in neutron, as well as some files on the filesystem.
  #2 From the ephemeral heat stack.

The code uses setdefault(), so in the case the value for a variable is available in the stage #1 this value is used in the inventory. In the case that `dns_search_domains` are defined in the baremetal deployment YAML definition[1] the `DnsSearchDomains` will be ignored. If `dns_search_domains` is not defined in the bm-deploy YAML `DnsSearchDomains` will be in the used to set the value in the inventory.


NOTE: If you don't set `dns_search_domains` in bm-deploy YAML the flag to enable network config update must be enabled to ensure the search domain is updated when config-download run the playbooks.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/provisioning/baremetal_provision.html#network-config-properties

openstack/block_storage/v3/host_extensio.message:
Are you sure? The API says the top-level key 'host' for the detail route [*] and 'hosts' for the list route, not 'host_extensions' for both as you've done here

Tip: In REST terminology, a list operation is typically defined as e.g. 'GET /resources', i.e. you're listing multiple resources. A fetch operation (a.k.a. show or detail) is typically defined as e.g. 'GET /resources/{id}', i.e. you're showing an individual resource whose identifier corresponds to '{id}'.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/?expanded=show-host-details-for-a-project-detail#hosts-extension-os-hosts
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/?expanded=list-all-hosts-for-a-project-detail#hosts-extension-os-hosts
This says that you should make your requests to '/v3/{project_id}/host_extension' (the '/v3/{project_id}' piece is derived from higher up the stack - you can ignore it for now). Are you sure?

Please also sort attributes in alphabetical order. We also miss some comments to each attribute ("#: Service status attribute"). Since this comments are used in the doc generation those would not be having any description.
This isn't necessary. openstacksdk will automatically "unpack" the response for you if you set the 'resource_key' (for detail operations) and 'resources_key' (for list operations) attributes.

openstack/block_storage/v3/_proxy.py.message:
I think you're muddling different things here. I appreciate that there are layers of indirection here so hopefully this will help. Apologies for the wall of text.

Everything inside these '_proxy' files can be thought of a "helper" or syntactic sugar. They let you do stuff like this:

  >>> import openstack
  >>> conn = openstack.connect()
  >>> conn.block_storage.availability_zones()
  [openstack.block_storage.v3.availability_zone.AvailabilityZone(zoneName=nova, zoneState={'available': True}, location=Munch({'cloud': 'envvars', 'region_name': 'RegionOne', 'zone': None, 'project': Munch({'id': '742ec5fd9b97453ba33643d8306e8a7b', 'name': 'demo', 'domain_id': 'default', 'domain_name': None})}))]

By comparison, this is what you need to do if you don't use this (you could of course simplify this and abstract it, but you get the idea):

  >>> from keystoneauth1.identity import v3
  >>> import keystoneauth1.session
  >>> from keystoneclient.v3 import client
  >>> from openstack.block_storage.v3 import availability_zone
  >>> import openstack.proxy
  >>> auth = v3.Password(auth_url='http://172.20.4.155/identity', username='admin', password='password', project_name='demo', user_domain_id='default', project_domain_id='default')
  >>> session = keystoneauth1.session.Session(auth=auth)
  >>> proxy = openstack.proxy.Proxy(session=session, service_type='block-storage', interface='public', version=3)
  >>> list(availability_zone.AvailabilityZone.list(session=adapter))
  [openstack.block_storage.v3.availability_zone.AvailabilityZone(zoneName=nova, zoneState={'available': True})]

So you can see why a normal user would want the proxy APIs 😉 Anywho, from the above we can see that we map the 'list' method of the resource, 'AvailabilityZone', to the 'availability_zones' proxy method, i.e.

  >>> conn.block_storage.availability_zones()

maps to and returns pretty much the same information as:

  >>> availability_zone.AvailabilityZone.list(session=adapter)

The way this mapping happens is by the 'availability_zones' proxy method calling the '_list' helper with the 'AvailabilityZone' class as an argument and isn't really something we really need to worry about here. Ultimately, the rule is:

- availability_zones -> AvailabilityZone.list  (via the '_list' helper)

Or, put more generically:

- resources -> Resource.list  (via the '_list' helper)

You'll also notice that there are no other availability zone-related proxy methods. That's because the 'AvailabilityZone' resource type has only specified 'allow_list = True', leaving the other methods to their default of 'False'.

  # capabilities
  allow_list = True

Ultimately this is done because the '/os-availability-zone' (apparently - it's not documented) only supports the list operation, i.e. 'GET /os-availability-zone' and not things like 'GET /os-availability-zone/{id}'. However, that's not the case for everything. Look at snapshots. There are no less than four snapshot-related methods here: 'create_snapshot', 'delete_snapshot', 'get_snapshot', 'find_snapshot', and 'snapshots'. Those all ultimately map to methods on the 'Snapshot' resource in 'openstack.block_storage.v3.snapshot':

- create_snapshot -> Snapshot.create  (via the '_create' helper)
- delete_snapshot -> Snapshot.delete  (via the '_delete' helper)
- get_snapshot -> Snapshot.fetch  (via the '_get' helper)
- find_snapshot -> Snapshot.find  (via the '_find' helper)
- snapshots -> Snapshot.list  (via the '_list' helper)

And if you look at the 'Snapshot' resource, you'll see they're all supported:

  # capabilities
  allow_fetch = True
  allow_create = True
  allow_delete = True
  allow_commit = True
  allow_list = True

Contrast this to your resource which has the following:

  allow_fetch = True
  allow_delete = True
  allow_list = True

You currently only have the one method here, 'get_messages'. Do you think (a) that this is named correctly and (b) that this is the only helper we need?

SDK's identity.project resource proxy does not support random properties as far as i see. For testing, I added a random property using an pre 0.90.0 SDK and tried to get the property back with SDK 0.90.0. It simply does not show up in the proxy object.

'properties' is not part of project anymore. It used to be a copy of project [1], the functionality still is in the sdk [2] but it is unused. But this is easy to fix: Instead of iterating over project.properties, iterate over projects directly.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/stable/train/openstack/cloud/_normalize.py#L716
[2] https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/cloud/_normalize.py#L728

https://github.com/openstack/ansible-collections-openstack/commit/c1a2496e0ff3e8b3d9b70cb8058834adb9b35099

In your recordset patch you moved the self.check_mode test upwards and out of the if-else-branches. Probably a good idea here as well to decrease level of indentations and improve code readability/visibility.

The SDK does not even send unknown resource attributes (what we call properties here) to OpenStack API when updating resources (projects). Hence we do not have to call update if properties is set because SDK wont do anything with them anyway.
This will throw a KeyError when k isn't in project.
If we filtered out in line 192 "description" it will fail here (what actually happens in tripleo job)

When state is absent, then name is allowed to be an ID, because it will only be used to find the project above.

When state is present and the project has to be created (which would require a name instead of an id), then project is none, so this conditional will not evaluate to true.

When state is present and the project already exists and the name does not match, then the user must have given an ID in 'name' (because if the user had given a name instead of an id, then find_project would have returned a project with a matching name only). In this case (user gave an id) we do not know whether the user wanted to update the name or not, because we only got an id. The user might have given the new name in 'properties' in which case our update mechanism would work just fine.

So I would simply drop this whole branch.
We filter out all non-set (None) values, should we?

Most modules including this one use 'None' values as indicators for 'user does not want to change this value'. This style might be debatable but that is how it was, so Rafael is being consistent here with the old behavior. If we want to change this, we should discuss and implement this across all modules imho.

When a project has been deleted in the previous paragraph, then project would be non-null and thus would be returned by self.exit_json(). In other modules return only 'changed' on state=='absent', hence we should do the same here for consistency.

This version solved this issue:
for BIOS mode it jumped into the submenu level immediately when using iso install.

The "DEFAULT XXX" in isolinux.cfg causes this issue. Use "menu start"+"menu default"+"ontimeout XXX" to realize this function:
for BIOS mode it stops at the main menu and highlights the default item by default, and when time out, the default "serial" in submenu boot up. Users can also get into the submenu to select between serial and graphical.

Could even do

 ring_dict = json.loads(reader.read_section('swift/metadata'))

The way Python does json.load() means there isn't any advantage to opening the section and working with a file-like: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/v3.10.0/Lib/json/__init__.py#L293

I was also debating about adding a RingReader.read_json() helper, but that's more for the symmetry with RingWriter.write_json() than any actual ergonomics.

Yes, I ended up trying their patch and it does what we want with OVS (as described in my own RFE) without touching OVS itself so I thought it was even better.

The only problem then is that the DHCP port which openstack thinks it can bind on each subnet of each segment of the network: it has one fixed address per subnet which means per segment, and that's not manageable on network layer 2. 

The patch in question, allowing multiple segments per physnet on a host, actually only binds the first segment, so, other fixed ips on different segments can't live on the same port.

Which is why I added the new PortConnectedToMultipleSegments exception, because it turns out removing HostConnectedToMultipleSegments exception only allows us to push back the limitation from host level to port level, not to actually remove it.

Which is also why I added the DHCP namespace port change proposal to the RFE. It's what will require most code change apparently.

Also, I changed the proposal to address the comments that were on the initial RFE.

Where do you suggest I go from here?

osc_lib/utils/__init__.py.message:
This is racy. If a migration is slow starting or the migration is not accepted, the instance can still be in active state when you get here. It's return False, but the answer is really only True in the latter case. Rather than checking this, you could check the '/servers/{id}/migrations' API [1], however, I can't find a good watch to get the migration record corresponding to a specific request...

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=id312-detail

Here we start monitoring the status of the instance after it has moved into migrating state. The instance status is set to migrating before actual migration tasks start [1]. So even if the migration is slow the instance status would stay in migrating status and we compare this to "active" in this function. So how could this lead to a race condition ?

Reg comparing the hypervisors, it will only check it after the status of instance has moved from migrating to active. Once the status changes from migrating to active we can be sure that the migration event has ended, the migration is then determined by comparing hyvervisors.

If you still think this can lead to race condition, can you suggest me some reproducer steps ?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/compute/api.py#L5091

what happens if the monitoring detects that the link is down for one of the directions? Will that affect the BGP peer?

What exactly do we want to monitor? The routes we advertise and/or the routes we learned from our peers and/or the connections between our speaker and its peers? Could you please explain what is the source and the destination in between we want to monitor connectivity? What action do we take when the monitoring status changes (both UP->DOWN and DOWN-UP)?

Monitoring is done towards the BGP peer. And when BFD detects the failure, it indicates that neighbor is not alive. Once that happens, all prefixes learned from the dead neighbor will be removed by BGP. Traffic gets rerouted through other paths incase if those are available.

The retype doesn't lock the rows, otherwise no operation would be able to happen while the retype is ongoing.

Which is not the point I'm trying to make here, and failing.

The thing is that now we do reservations like this: -1 volumes_<source_volume_type> -1 gigabytes_<source_volume_type> +1 volumes_<destination_volume_type> +1 gigabytes_<destination_volume_type>

But that is wrong, because freeing resources from the source type means that some other operation can consume those and if the retype fails and we have to rollback the reservations we may end up with over quota on the source volume type.

So while a retype is ongoing we need to consume type resources in both the source and the destination.
I understand the point, i was just trying to clear the confusion i had regarding the locking mechanism. Now i understand that we are referring to reservations here and not quota.

Sorry for being quota illiterate. So currently when we create a resource, let's say volume, and it goes in error state (let's say scheduler is down), does it count in the quotas? If not, seems like we are going to change that behavior. I'm not sure about if it is good to count a resource in quotas if it doesn't consume any actual space on the backend and is just a DB record? but then again maybe determining that would be a complex thing.

Current behavior is a mess, it all comes down to when/where things fail and what failure we have.

When creating a volume, if the cinder API is able to send the request to the scheduler and it fails to schedule, then the volume will have consumed quota. 

But if the failure happens on the API node after the volume has been created in the DB and before we commit the reservations, then the volume will not have consumed quota.

I think in one hand we should make things easy to understand from a user perspective (if it's there and is using quota, then it's counted), and even if we could change the SQL query to not count volumes that are in ERROR status and do not have a host/cluster field, this could be a problem for an admin, because a user script could suddenly create a million volume records if the scheduler is rejecting the request.

That's what I was trying to convey in that paragraph.

I think I named it `vol_total_size` because at some point I named had named `vol_gbs` as `vol_size` and wanted to make the distinction.

Though now I think it would be clearer to name it `vol_size` instead, since the word total causes more confusion than help.

Changing it to `vol_size`.

Actually, we do *not* want to check per_volume_size_limit explicitly (it's sort of checked indirectly because that limit is what's used if per_volume_gigabytes is not set on a project).  It's counterintuitive, but a common use case is that an operator wants the max size to be N for most projects, and only wants a few projects to have volumes of max size M>N.  Allowing the quota to be set to exceed the limit makes it easy to do that.

what do we mean by * here?

That's python PEP 3102 [1] for keyword-only arguments, so when a caller passes any of the arguments after the * it must use keywords and cannot use them as positional.

So a caller cannot do:

  quota_driver.vol_snap_check_and_reserve_cm(context, type_id, type_name,
                                     project_id, uuid)

They have to do:

  quota_driver.vol_snap_check_and_reserve_cm(context, type_id, type_name,
                                     project_id, uuid=uuid)


[1]: https://peps.python.org/pep-3102/

I'll create a blueprint if it is needed, but I'm not convinced multipath capability should be selected by users.

Usage of multipath is dependent on backend storage and for some backend there is no "multipath" concept(eg, ceph, NFS, ...). IMO multipath should be enabled according to the infrastructure design and something operators instead of users should select.

It's true that this can change the API behavior, but the main intention of this change is not to introduce any API change but to let operators notice their misconfiguration. The enforcement is still optional and disabled by default. Users are responsible to enable multipath properly if they want to enable it.

by the way if the volume had some metadata on it that carried the requirement for multi attach we could include that in the schduleing request and test that in the nova api as part of attch.

that would be similer to how neutron qos for minium bandwith works.

we do not need to have operators expictly request the traits in flavor or images we can interpert the atributes on the volumes via a prefileter for schduling and in the atach api to validate if the host has multiatch enabled.

basically only the libvirt hosts that have multipath enabled would report the multipath trait. when we get the attach request we can test if the host has that trait if the volume requires multiattach.

the spec freeze for zed is thrusday so it will be hard to create one in time but im happy to review a spec on this topic if you have one or we can reivew this for next cycle.

this is a feature not a bug so at a minium this need a blueprint but if we are going to enforce multipath im not convinced we should do it via a host level config.

i would prefer to model this via traits and have host report multipath support only if its aviable on the host and then model enforcement with a requried trait.

we should not have the vm creation or volume attachmenet fail because of a config option you cannot schdule on. this would be undiscoverable config driven api behavior which is not something we should add more of.

so -2 is because of lack of spec to describe this feature and because directionally this is config driven api behaivor.

we could support multipath enforcement in nova but we should not take this approch to do so.

FWIW, the stable policy allows us to backport a change that's not purely a bugfix :

"It’s nevertheless allowed to backport fixes for other bugs if their safety can be easily proved. For example, documentation fixes, debug log message typo corrections, test only changes, patches that enhance test coverage, configuration file content fixes can apply to all supported branches. For those types of backports, stable maintainers will decide on case by case basis."
https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#appropriate-fixes

So we can propose a backport to stable/yoga if we want without proper Launchpad tracking.
